content: vanilla socks for dad men s size 11 shoe these socks are plain vanilla socks they are knit from the top down with a french heel and a standard round toe these socks were knit for my dad who is a very knit worthy person they are made to be exactly the way he likes his socks i found the book the sock knitter s handbook by charlene schurch and beth parrott to be extraordinarily helpful in creating this pattern the book has everything you could possibly need to create your own custom pair of socks i highly recommend checking it out if you are interested in customizing socks for yourself i used suggestions for gauge materials dimensions and heel and toe measurements from the book but all the selecting and combining and experimenting was done myself materials 100g fingering weight sock yarn i used 2 50g skeins of patons kroy sock yarn in the blue striped ragg color way for my first making of these socks you can use whatever you like us size 2 2 75mm double pointed knitting needles or size needed to get gauge or whichever needle configuration you prefer whether that be magic loop 2 circulars or a 9 inch circular my instructions will be written for dpns as that is what i use for socks and that is what i have experience with but feel free to adapt the pattern to your preferred needles a standard set of knitting notions including a tape measure or ruler a row counter scissors stitch markers i like the locking kind and a tapestry needle optional point protectors 2 sets seam ripper or other pointy object for fraying yarn ends progress keeper small crochet hook for fixing mistakes crochet thread for lifelines gauge 8 sts/inch in stockinette stitch in the round unblocked directions cuff/leg co 72 stitches onto 3 needles using your favorite stretchy cast on i use the german twisted co for all my top-down socks i absolutely love it now different people divide their stitches on their needles different ways i prefer to put half the stitches on the first needle and 1/4 of the stitches on the other two needles here to make the ribbing easier i put 36 stitches on needle 1 20 stitches on needle 2 and 16 stitches on needle 3 join being careful not to twist the stitches and work in 2x2 rib for 1 1/2 inches for the cuff you can place a marker for the beginning of the round but i find that i don t have to as i know the beginning of the round is right before the needle with the most stitches switch to stockinette stitch and knit the leg of the sock until the piece measures 7 3/4 inches long when i switch to stockinette i make the two smaller needles even with their number of stitches so i have 36 stitches on needle 1 18 stitches on needle 2 and 18 stitches on needle
